newsitem.title: TANZANIA: Canadian firm in Tanzanian nickel, cobalt venture.
newsitem.headline: Canadian firm in Tanzanian nickel, cobalt venture.

text.p: Canadian firm Sutton Resources Ltd will sign a $25 million joint venture agreement next week covering its Kabanga nickel and cobalt deposit in northwest Tanzania, a senior company official said on Tuesday.
Sutton's resident director, Bill Bali, told Reuters that its locally incorporated company, Kabanga Nickel Ltd, would enter into the agreement as a junior partner.
"A deal will be signed on July 21 in (the Tanzanian town of) Dodoma between Sutton Resources Ltd and a large South African mining house. This will be for a joint venture," he said.
Bali said the name of the South African partner would be revealed on the signing day.
Australian mining giant The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd (BHP) withdrew from the Kabanga project in mid-1996.
Bali said Sutton geologists had projected a potential deposit of one billion pounds of nickel and 120 million pounds of cobalt at its prospect in Ngara in northwest Tanzania.
"In terms of geological grade, the nickel is two percent above average while the cobalt is a co-product and not a by-product," said Bali.
He added: "Something like $25 million will be spent on the project to bring it up to feasibility phase towards the end of the millennium."

If a decision was taken to develop the deposit, the estimated cost of bringing the nickel/cobalt prospect into full production was about $250 million compared to about $175 million for Sutton's gold deposit at Bulyankulu.

A nickel plant requires heavy power usage of about 35 megawatts compared to 10 megawatts for gold. A 10-megawatt gold plant could process about 4,000 tonnes of ore per day while the 35-megawatts required for nickel/cobalt would handle between 10,000 and 20,000 tonnes per day, Bali said.
Tanzania is experiencing an upsurge of activity in its embryonic mining sector, particularly among gold explorers whose main focus is the potentially lucrative Lake Victoria goldfield.
Four major gold projects, each with a resource base in excess of one million ounces, could be in production within the next four years.

Kahama Mining Corp, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sutton, is developing a world-class gold project at Bulyankulu in the Lake Victoria goldfields and expects to pour its first gold from the fully-commissioned mine in 1999.
